docs.lead_paragraph: TO hear lobbyists and lawmakers in Washington tell it, giving patients the right to sue insurers that refuse to approve medical treatment would be either the death of managed care or the salvation of patients. If Federal protection against such suits is eliminated, ''you'd have businesses dropping health care coverage right and left,'' warned Mark Merritt, a vice president of the American Association of Health Plans.

headline.main: In Texas, a Laboratory Test on the Effects of Suing H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Texas, where procedures are in place to appeal insurance decisions and sue HMOs, is test ground for proposed Federal legislation to protect patient rights; insurers have issued dire warnings of detimental effects on health care, but actual increase in premiums in Texas has been only 0.1 percent, compared with projected nationwide costs of 1.2 percent under Democratic proposal; Texas doctors do report that HMOs are showing more willingness to accept treatment decisions, and costs are not spiraling; several Texas cases reviewed: Leon Hand suffered stroke after managed-care doctor refused to admit him to hospital, and later settled with Humana; Dora Cisneros successfully appealed health plan's denial of pain-management therapy; phtoos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY their own admission, both are political mavericks. He, a longtime Westchester Democrat known for breaking the rules, won his first elected office as a County Legislator and became Supervisor of Greenburgh seven years ago. She, the Lieutenant Governor of New York and a former Republican, was the protegee of Gov. George E. Pataki before changing parties and seeking to unseat her mentor. As is often said, politics makes strange bedfellows, and the apparently unlikely pairing on the campaign trail this summer of Supervisor Paul J. Feiner, 42, a candidate for Congress in the 20th District -- which includes parts of Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties -- and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, 49, a gubernatorial candidate, has looked to most observers like an example of that old saw. They endorsed each other at a news conference in Greenburgh earlier this summer and have appeared together before voters at supermarkets and train stations on many occasions in the last several months.

headline.main: Partnership Of Affinity That Defies Affiliations

docs.abstract: Article on unlikely pairing of Supervisor Paul Feiner of Greenburgh, NY, and state Lieutenant Gov Betsy McCaughey Ross; Feiner is District 20 Congressional candidate and Ross is gubernatorial candidate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: While deploring the loss of his own privacy this summer, President Clinton set out boldly to invade mine. His Administration promised me a healthier life if I would accept assignment of a computer code -- a number or thumb print or retina marker or other electronic gizmo to be called a U.H.I., a unique health identifier. It would instantly disclose my medical record to anyone needing to treat me anywhere, and also to those who labor to improve medical science with research. Before I could even calculate the probable costs and benefits of U.H.I.'s, shouts of protest forced the President to retreat. Americans, it seems, fear snoops even more than they fear germs. Many, in fact, responded as if their privacy were an absolute right, guaranteed by the Constitution and not available for negotiation.
docs.abstract: Max Frankel's Word & Image column examines privacy issues raised by Clinton Administration's abortive attempts to assign computer-coded unique health identifier to every American that could instantly disclose medical records to health providers and researchers anywhere (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bitter weeklong teachers' strike at the 17 schools in this sprawling central New Jersey suburb ended this morning about an hour before a court hearing in which a judge was to consider dismissing 800 striking teachers. After a night of bargaining, negotiators for the school board and the local teachers' union accepted a state labor conciliator's proposal for a contract about 7:50 A.M. By doing so, the union spared its members possible job sanctions or jail sentences, and the board freed itself from a union accusation that it had violated a state labor law by imposing a contract on teachers last July.

headline.main: Middletown Township Teachers End Their Weeklong Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: THE mail included a handy guide to Tuesday's Democratic primary that was prepared by the Citizens Union, an organization usually described as a good-government group. (How come you never hear about bad-government groups?) The booklet was indeed informative, especially about the sad state of voter interest in New York politics. According to Conn Nugent, the union's executive director, something like 10,000 copies of the booklet have been sent out, a far cry from the 25,000 that was typical for primaries in the early 1950's. ''Information is not nearly as much in demand as it once was,'' Mr. Nugent lamented. ''What there is, in mountains, is apathy.''

headline.main: Guide of Sorts To Just Who Is on Ballot

docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column discusses his impressions of Geraldine Ferraro, Charles E Schumer and Mark Green, Democratic candidates for US Senate, and Peter F Vallone, Charles J Hynes and James L Larocca, Democratic candidates for Governor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders challenged the heart of President Clinton's domestic policy strategy today, saying they would press for a tax cut worth up to $80 billion over five years and pay for it by dipping into projected Federal budget surpluses. Their decision puts House Republicans -- already considering impeachment proceedings against the President -- on another collision course with the White House. Mr. Clinton has insisted that the surplus be set aside until Congress and the Administration have agreed on a plan to shore up the Social Security system.

headline.main: House Republicans to Push for Tax Cut Worth Up to $80 Billion

docs.lead_paragraph: A consortium representing 25,000 doctors said yesterday that it was stepping up legal action against Ox- ford Health Plans over more than $140 million in unpaid fees. The action comes after more than six months of fruitless negotiations in the dispute with New York's largest health maintenance organization, according to the New York County Medical Society. The society, together with 13 other doctors' groups, has accused the insurer of ''a pattern of delays, denials and detours from acceptable practice'' in failing to pay doctors for as long as a year after seeing Oxford patients. Oxford, based in Norwalk, Conn., has called the $140 million figure a ''substantial overstatement.'' The company did not return a call for comment yesterday. Oxford has said it pays most of its doctor bills within 30 days. But the doctors said the company paid only after a long wait or prodding from them.

headline.main: Metro Business; Doctors Press Claims On Oxford Health

docs.lead_paragraph: Yale University's medical school will pay $5.6 million to the Federal government, the state and several private insurance companies to settle a three-year investigation into questionable billing. The insurance companies that were overbilled include Aetna, Travelers, Prudential, Blue Cross and Blue Shield, and Metropolitan. The settlement calls for Yale to pay approximately $2.5 million to the state, about $1.9 million to private insurers, and $1.2 million to the Federal Government. Yale will also file advertisements in several newspapers this week to notify patients who may be entitled to about $620,000 in refunds. It was the largest settlement ever for a civil health care case in Connecticut, according to the United States Attorney's office.

headline.main: $5.6 Million Settlement By Yale Medical School

docs.lead_paragraph: Like thousands of other elderly Americans, Eugene DeLorenzo cannot find a Medicare health maintenance organization in his area. Mr. DeLorenzo, a 75-year-old retired real estate broker and his wife, Yuriko, enrolled July 1 in the Medicare plan of Healthnet, a unit of Foundation Health Systems Inc. Just three weeks later, Healthnet, unable to make a strong profit in the rural Northern California county where Mr. DeLorenzo lives, said it was ending its coverage there.

headline.main: Medicare Panacea Turns Patient; H.M.O's Now Must Treat Their Own Ills

docs.abstract: Many of nation's health maintenance organizations, after aggressively recruiting elderly and disabled into their Medicare plans, are heavily retreating; United Healthcare Corp, once darling of Wall Street, recently took $900 million charge against earnings, in part to scale back its Medicare operations in 35 counties; in last year, Aetna, Pacificare Health Systems, Oxford Health Plans, Foundation Health Systems, Kaiser Permanente and Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations have canceled Medicare plans in parts of 13 states; virtually no Medicare HMO's are available in Utah or in rural Ohio; despite HMO financial problems in Medicare market, Congress is now pushing for even more people to enroll in plans; financial setbacks for some HMO's have raised serious questions as to whether they can prosper covering Medicare patients; charts; photo of Eugene and Yuriko DeLorenzo, who have had their Medicare coverage canceled (M)
